data.name: Linear interpolation of hex color codes
data.description:
*"In mathematics, linear interpolation is a method of curve fitting using linear polynomials to construct new data points within the range of a discrete set of known data points."* - Wikipedia

In simpler terms, linear interpolation (or "lerp" for short) is when you find the coordinates of a point that lies on a straight line between two other points.

You are given two color codes in hexadecimal format, `color_1` and `color_2`. Your task is to find the hex color code that lies between these two colors, at distance `d` away from the first color.

When `d = 0`, the desired color code has no distance from `color_1`, so you should simply return `color_1`.

Similarily, when `d = 1`, you should just return `color_2`.

`d` can be any value from 0 to 1. The larger its value, the further away from `color_1` the desired color is and the closer it is to `color_2`. For example, `d = 0.5` means the desired color is exactly between the two given colors, whereas `d = 0.9` means the color is very close to `color_2`.

If the given color codes are not in hexadecimal format, return the message `"Invalid color codes"`. You can assume that `d` will always be in the range `0 <= d <= 1`.

Make sure to round any values you use in your output to the nearest integer, or up if a value is equally close to two integers. Your output should also be in hexadecimal format.

Some examples:
```python
hex_color_lerp("abcdef", "a", 0.5) -> "Invalid color codes"

hex_color_lerp("#abcde", "gggggg", 0.5) -> "Invalid color codes"

hex_color_lerp("000000", "ffffff", 0.5) -> "808080"

hex_color_lerp("000000", "ffffff", 0.2) -> "333333"

hex_color_lerp("a1b2c3", "6f5e4d", 0.77) -> "7a7168"
```
Good luck!
